Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Intelligent Planning and Control Software for EV Charging Infrastructure
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to develop smart software to plan and control Electric Vehicle (EV) charging infrastructure in commercial facilities, such as workplaces, hotels, car rental centers, parking garages, etc. The EV planning software finds the optimal design balancing design tradeoffs such as EV customer satisfaction, grid stability limits and financial constraints. This software will help facility operators to optimize their EV charging infrastructure by minimizing their operating costs and maximizing their revenue by utilizing intelligent scheduling and pricing strategies. The software leverages the latest developments in stochastic optimization for designing an optimal configuration of EV infrastructure that is robust to variations in mobility behavior of the users. This will enable public utilities to save billions of dollars by deferring expensive upgrades to their existing infrastructure. It will also empower small consulting businesses, facility managers and electrical contractors to design and build EV infrastructure without any specialized knowledge of optimization or modeling.

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project addresses the problem of planning and controlling EV charging infrastructure to meet the rapidly growing energy demands of EV owners. EVs are expected to comprise 30% of all cars globally by 2030. This forecasted increase over the next 10 years is of major concern for utilities, and commercial real estate owners. Given the long commute distances, driving habits, time taken to charge using home-based chargers and range anxiety, there is a need for charging locations at workplaces, hotels, and car rental centers. Chargers at these locations will generally be medium power Level 2 chargers, which are 5 to 10 times the size of typical home chargers. Simultaneous uncontrolled charging of several EVs at these locations will easily overload the local electrical infrastructure. The software mitigates this problem by designing an optimal EV infrastructure together with optimally sized onsite generation and storage. The controlling solution ensures that the grid impacts are minimized by scheduling the installed EV chargers together with onsite generation and storage with optimal set points in real time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
STTR Phase I: Intelligent Planning and Control Software for EV Charging

Background: Many cities have started electrifying their buses and fleets requiring installation of charging infrastructure both at depots and along the routes. At high levels of penetration this will require significant upgrades to the electrical infrastructure at the facility as well as to the grid. This is not limited to heavy vehicles. Simultaneous charging of several electric cars at locations like workplace, hotels, parking garages etc. could also overload the local electrical infrastructure.

To address this problem an intelligent planning and control system for electric vehicle charging infrastructure was developed by Microgrid Labs together with the University of California, Berkeley. The software has two parts: planning and controlling. Each fulfills different needs as described below.

Planning Software: The challenge of planning is to determine the optimal infrastructure sizing that will minimize investments, meet operational requirements, and eliminate any adverse impact on the electrical network. The planning software models the driving and charging process to design an optimally sized EV infrastructure considering mobility behavior, vehicle interchange time, waiting time, queue lengths, electrical network limits, and budget considerations.

Operational Controller: The controlling module of the software optimizes the operation of the entire system in real time (EV fleet, onsite generation, onsite storage, and non-EV loads) to minimize operational costs. Based on model predictive control, it continuously optimizes the operation based on mobility behavior, network limits, queue management and pricing strategies

Stage of development:

We have already completed the Alpha version of the planning software and are using them in pilot projects. An operational controller is still at a prototype stage.

Intellectual Merit

Planning Software addresses a mathematical optimization problem with uncertain inputs, high service level demand and challenging design tradeoffs. These include

  • Incorporating uncertainty in mobility behavior ? arrival/departure times, state of charge upon arrival/departure, time for vehicle interchange and overstay.
  • Incorporating uncertainty in facility loads and solar irradiance.
  • Incorporating interchange time (time taken to move vehicles in and out). Interchange happens when chargers are shared, and vehicles are charged one after another. Charger remains connected but not used during interchanges, thus reducing resource availability.
  • Managing the tradeoff between customer expectations and cost ? customer expectation of high service levels (fulfilling desired state of charge and low waiting times) and cost of providing service (capacity of chargers and charging schedule).
  • Enabling scalability and speed by using polynomial-time convex optimization solvers that incorporate robustness to uncertainty. This is done using a novel combination of chanced constrained optimization and two-stage stochastic programming.

Planning software has two distinct components

  • An optimizer algorithm based on aggregate demand and supply in Python that incorporates uncertainty in mobility behavior, facility loads, solar irradiance, overstay and interchange time (time taken to move vehicles in and out). Interchange happens when chargers are shared, and vehicles are charged one after another.
  • As the optimizer does not address queuing challenges, we developed a discrete event simulator, also in Python. The simulator validates and when needed adjusts the recommendations from the optimizer to resolve queuing challenges.
  • To make this a complete solution the software platform will eventually integrate FastSim Software of NREL for vehicle battery sizing

Broader/Commercial Impact

Commercial Impact: We are testing the planning software in multiple pilot projects. Several transit agencies and consulting firms have evinced interest in using the planning solution for optimal sizing of their EV charging infrastructure to minimize their investment and operational costs

The controller, when fully developed, will allow these facilities to optimally operate the chargers to minimize operational costs and grid impact, while achieving revenue and service goals.

Broader Impact: This project will promote easy and smooth transition to e-Mobility and will help society achieve environmental and sustainability goals.
